contents.markdown: Conjunctions are words that join words, phrases, clauses or sentences. There are many, and I have included nine of the most common ones above. Because you have already been using _at, nun, kapag_ and _kung_ already, we will not discuss them anymore in this lesson.
These are all used in the same way; you just put them between the items to join. One note about _kasi_– we are using it to mean “because” rather than the conjunctive adverb _dahil sa_ in this book.

item.tagalog: Ibigay mo ang pera sa akin o kunin mo ang pagkain.
item.english: Give the money to me or get the food.

item.tagalog: Gusto kitang ibili ng mangga, pero hindi puwede.
item.english: I want to buy you a mango, but cannot.

item.tagalog: Nasa kalsada ako, kaya nakikita ko ang ulan.
item.english: I am in the street, so I can see the rain.

item.tagalog: Pagod siya kasi naglaro sila ng basketbol.
item.english: He is tired because they played basketball.

contents.markdown: You have been using _para_ as a preposition:

item.tagalog: Nag-aral ako sa eskuwelahan para sa guro ko.
item.english: I studied in school for my teacher.

contents.markdown: In this lesson, we will use it as a conjunction that means “in order to” or just “to”. If you recall, the verb + infinitive structure works for certain verbs:

item.tagalog: Sinubukang kunin ng bata ang pera.
item.english: The kid tried to take the money.

contents.markdown: For all other verbs, _para_ is used. It is a little different from the conjunctions mentioned previously because when it is followed by a verb, the verb takes the infinitive.
Item1 + para + item2. = Item1 in order to item2.
**Note: If item2 starts with a verb, the verb takes infinitive.**

item.tagalog: Nagluto ako ng manok para kumain sa kuwarto ko.
item.english: I cooked chicken to eat in my room.

item.tagalog: Makukuha ni Joe ang basketbol para maglaro bukas.
item.english: Joe will be able to get the basketball to play tomorrow.

item.tagalog: Inilalagay ko ang tsokolate sa lamesa para maalala ito.
item.english: I am putting the chocolate on the table to remember it.

item.tagalog: Nagluto ako ng manok upang kumain sa kuwarto ko.
item.english: I cooked chicken to eat in my room.

contents.markdown: But _upang_ is a less common, so we will not use it anymore in this book.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Sabi ba niya, nalaman ni Angel, o hindi mo alam?
exampleSentences.english: Did she say Angel found out, or do you not know?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Sa tingin ko, magugustuhan mo ang Seattle, pero hindi ang ulan dun.
exampleSentences.english: I think you will like Seattle, but not the rain there.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Nahirapan siyang magtanim ng mga puno, kaya umalis siya.
exampleSentences.english: He was having a hard time planting trees, so he left.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Mapupuntahan ni Joe ang Pilipinas kasi nag-aral siya ng Tagalog.
exampleSentences.english: Joe will be able to go to the Philippines, because he studied Tagalog.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Nagbisikleta ba kayo sa Cebu para maranasan ninyo ang halo-halo?
exampleSentences.english: Did you (pl.) bike to Cebu to experience the halo-halo?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Kailangan ba nating maglakad sa ibabaw o sa tabi nito?
exampleSentences.english: Do we (incl.) need to walk above or beside it?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Pwede kang mag-alala tungkol dito, pero huwag.
exampleSentences.english: You can worry about it, but don’t.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Hindi ko alam kung nasaan siya, kaya hinahanap ko siya.
exampleSentences.english: I do not know where she is, so I am looking for her.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Baka pagod si David kasi naglaro siya talaga nang marami.
exampleSentences.english: Maybe David is tired because he really played a lot.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Nagluluto siya tuwing Miyerkules para kumain sa atin.
exampleSentences.english: She cooks every Wednesday to eat at our (incl.) place.
